Entry.1:
We left the hut mentioned above on morning of August 31, and marched toward the now ever shifting "Front Line". One time the "front line" meant an elaborate system of drained & revetted and duck boarded trenches with crude shelters (called by courtesy, Dugouts – but now it is a very "sparsely populated" line of soldiers crouching in any cutting, declivity, hole or trench that offers itself: soldiers who just wait long enough to draw breath and open a tin of Bully, and then move on if so be it is their fortune to be able.

Halting at noon near some Eighteen Pounder Batteries we stayed there for an hour and then continued our journey forward – a Berlin. Fritz put up a terrific bombardment on the road and it is marvellous how so many of us escaped death.

If ever this is read it will doubtless occur to the reader that I have too often reiterated this statement. But every day that one survives in this shell swept area is to me - and must be, I think, to any who seriously reflect – at once a bewilderment a marvel and a miracle.

About 3 in the afternoon we halted beside the Somme in a railway cutting - and here for 8 hours we were subjected to a merciless bombardment by heavy artillery. And during the whole

of the hours of daylight, platoon after platoon, company after company, battalion after battalion, hove into sight across the stream, sauntered placidly and slowly – or was it wearily and apathetically – along the shell torn road, crossed the narrow, crude, wooden bridge across the Somme, and nestled close as they could under one of those almost perpendicular heights of this region, there to wait till the friendly but portentious darkness made it possible to struggle further on. I shall never forget the heroism of a few engineers who amid a tornado of shells kept repairing this little bridge across the river. Shell after shell burst alongside them with a deafening roar and splashed the water mountain high, yet they went on with their work unperturbed and unhurried as though they were working in the peaceful solitudes of their own Australian bushland; and they never desisted while the light was good. They seemed to bear charmed 
lif
 lives until the dusk fell and their task was done. With the waning of the day the troops who were to participate in tomorrow’s orgie were disposed in the cracks and crevices on the right side of the Somme and the little bridge, with the help of the dauntless engineers had served its immediate purpose, and the former was waiting demolition by a well directed shell, and the latter

were busily engaged in preparing their "supper". Some were attending the fire which had been lighted under the foot of the cutting – rather an audacious precedent considering our proximity to the foe and the activity of his planes – some were sitting round and smoking, and others chopping. Nearly all were singing snatches of the latest songs (for it is marvellous how quickly the choruses find their way from the London Theatres to The Front). Fritz had shortened his range and his shells were bursting just on the edge of the bank. Somehow I sensed an impending catastrophe. Those most concerned didn’t: or, sensing it, took no notice. A flash of light, a more angry crash than usual, and Death had descended and gathered those gallant souls into eternity.

But why particularize when

"Death is here, Death is there

Death is busy everywhere."

Cappy Sept. 23/1918

Since writing last nothing of importance has happened. We are still in the same place, doing the same things i.e. a little drill and a few games each day and plenty of sleep each night. For we are making up for those "Days of danger, Nights of waking" up at Mt. St. Quentin.

Not far from here is a fifteen inch gun, captured by the first Brigade, towards the end of August. I have been over to see it on two occasions and I think it is a triumph of implacable ingenuity. The barrel is about 45 feet long, measures 7 feet in circumference at the muzzle and 15 feet at the breech. It has been use – four shells are supposed to have been fired from it, most likely upon Amiens which is distant about 30 Kilos for the trees towards the front are blackened and blasted and withered. It is thought that the gun was blown up by the bursting of a shell in the barrel ("a premature burst") although it is not known definitely. Whatever the cause the explosion must have been terrific, for solid pieces of steel weighing almost a ton each are lying about the site; and I saw one piece weighing fully 6 cwt. lying 8 hundred yards away. The thickness of the steel at the breech is 13 inches and this has been shattered into great jagged

splinters that now hang down and testify to the awful power of the Bosche H.E. The circular platform on which the gun revolves is fully 20 yards in diameter. And this monster was doubtless put there for the purpose of hurling shells a ton weight among the unsuspecting residents of Amiens. Many a leisurely stroll I have had across these quondam lovely fields of Picardy and marvelled at the profusion of cornflowers and poppies that almost hide the ugly shell holes and uglier trenches; and I wonder if those responsible for the war could have "dipt into the future" and seen the result to this rich and beautiful land, would they have been demoniac enough to have launched it on the world.

Padre Buckley gave us a nice little talk about "writing home" on Sunday – how the poor old Mother would wait and watch and hunger for news from France – and I can just imagine my old Mother and wee sister watching for Postie. Not that I ever miss when it is possible to write but –

Again he’s gone, O God! No look, no sign

The cruel Postman’s past my gate again.

My son! My Son! No letter – not one line.

For hours I’ve stood here in the wind and rain.

And watched the busy traffic thread the street:

Or saw at times a yellow, winter’s leaf

As down it whirled and rested at my feet

Like some dead Hope that mocks a living grief.

- These things I saw; yet as from far off lands.

One form alone was plain to these old eyes,

And it was marked as suppliant marks the hands

That Heart’s Desire gives, or else denies

I saw him turn the corner and stroll on,

All careless of the precious freight he bore.

He slowly oped a gate and crossed a lawn,

And, standing framed within a neighbour’s door

Blew that shrill note, that music makes to ears

Of Mother, Sister, Sweetheart, daughter, Wife;

Makes hearts to leap for joy and calms the fears

For him so far away in that red strife.

He gave the boon to trembling hands and turned:

And Fancy said "He’s crossing to 
your
 gate"

"Behold that well-loved scrawl of his." I yearned

To grasp my prize, but something bade me wait.

… And now he’s gone, and my old eyes are dim.

A blackness surges o’er me like a sea.

All Hope is gone. Forgotten – and by him

Whose love was all that Life held dear to me.

Week after week I’ve striven to trace my heart,

In ill-formed characters; with Time-tired hands

And tear-dimmed eyes; and heeded not the smart

For what do these things count when Love commands.

… Hadst thou remembered son, I could have borne

The utter weariness for Love’s dear sake.

Thou lovest me not: so everything is gone.

My heart is chilled O God! that it could break!

I know things take on a more sombre hue when

my
 letters do not come.

I crouch low in the cold muddy trenches

As the bullets go whistling by

And the shells go shrieking and screaming

And the flashes are brightening the sky.

The thunders on thunders go rolling

As the Titans their awful bolts hurl

But I’m wondering and wondering and wondering

Why no letter comes out from the girl.

Now the daylight the darkness is hustling

And the flashes grow dim in the dawn

The night of our watching is over

And the moment of Zero rolls on

The world seems to crumble beneath us

Yet
 Out there, in the Devil’s mad whirl

Yet vaguely and dimly I’m wondering

Why no letter comes out from the girl.

We are out of the trench, in the open.

Now each moment is surely out last ….

Tirancourt
Entry.2:
…. Well we all got within a hundred yards of the tape before he secured a hit. Then a salvo of 5.9’s came over and one landed right amongst our column. I do not know how many were rendered Hors De Combat by the burst for we could not stop to see, but I know they were lying round and groaning as I passed on. When we had at last taken our position on the tape there was still a few minutes to wait for the opening of our artillery barrage – a few minutes to dream of days gone by, and friends and dear ones far away; to say Goodbye to everything and prepare ourselves for the end: for he is an optimist indeed who crosses that narrow white line in the early dawn in the expectation of returning.

Fritz was still pounding away persistently and doing his best to interrupt our reflections; when a terrific roar, which made the hills rock and reverberate, told us that the game was afoot, and we began at once to advance.

All frailties, failings, fears and feelings were left behind when we stepped into No Man’s Land; and we went forward, more like marionettes

than men quite oblivious of all externalities. If a shell burst 100 yards away from us as we were coming up there would be an irresistible desire to duck, and a shudder of dread would run down our backs; but now they were bursting within 5 yards and exciting no emotion. Sometimes we would see a gap made in our ranks, sometimes a comrade alongside would fall, perhaps to lie there, or perhaps to immediately rise and make for the rear with a swinging arm, a limping leg or bleeding face, but these things had nothing to do with us, and left us quite unaffected.

All 
we
 had to do was to walk leisurely, mechanically forward, through the smoke and smell and din, behind our creeping barrage – and forward we went. We had gone about 300 yards from the "hopping off" tape before our little party paid mortal toll to the enemy; though shells seemed to be falling on every foot that held no man. Just then our officer ("Stan" Bennie, who had used his own field dressing on my head at Albert in April) came over to Dick Moore and me and for a moment we stood there – I between the two – in that scene of utter confusion, unconscious of any

extraordinary sensation and feeling in no way out of our natural environment, remarking casually on the intensity and effect of our barrage, and waiting for it to lift.

A couple of hundred yards from us, across the valley, a score of Germans were scampering up the hill. "Put a burst into them" said Bennie, "Set down and take your time", so I got down and sent a shower of lead amongst the unfortunate wretches. Down they went as if blown over by a strong 
burst
 gust of wind. Simultaneously with my firing an enemy machine gun opened up on us from close in front.

Almost with the first shot I saw Bennie put his hand to his breast turn away and lie gently on the ground. I turned my head silently toward Dick Moore to see him let go his rifle and grasp at his face and I knew he had received a "Blighty", an "Aussie" or a "France" for the whole of his cheek had been blown away by an explosive bullet.
